my judgment told me that we must have been
several hours in this strange world.

3146.text:
Presently the forest terminated, and we came
out upon a level plain. A short distance before

3151.text:
us rose a few low, rocky hills. Toward these
our captors urged us, and after a short time

3159.text:
led us through a narrow pass into a tiny,
circular valley. Here they got down to work,

3165.text:
and we were soon convinced that if we were
not to die to make a Roman holiday, we were

3169.text:
to die for some other purpose. The attitude
of our captors altered immediately as they

3175.text:
entered the natural arena within the rocky
hills. Their laughter ceased. Grim ferocity

3182.text:
marked their bestial faces—bared fangs menaced
us.

3186.text:
We were placed in the center of the amphitheater—the
thousand creatures forming a great ring about

3191.text:
us. Then a wolf-dog was brought—HYAENODON
Perry called it—and turned loose with us

3197.text:
inside the circle. The thing's body was as
large as that of a full-grown mastiff, its

3203.text:
legs were short and powerful, and its jaws
broad and strong. Dark, shaggy hair covered

3210.text:
its back and sides, while its breast and belly
were quite white. As it slunk toward us it

3217.text:
presented a most formidable aspect with its
upcurled lips baring its mighty fangs.

3223.text:
Perry was on his knees, praying. I stooped
and picked up a small stone. At my movement

3228.text:
the beast veered off a bit and commenced circling
us. Evidently it had been a target for stones

3235.text:
before. The ape-things were dancing up and
down urging the brute on with savage cries,

3240.text:
until at last, seeing that I did not throw,
he charged us.

3245.text:
At Andover, and later at Yale, I had pitched
on winning ball teams. My speed and control

3252.text:
must both have been above the ordinary, for
I made such a record during my senior year

3256.text:
at college that overtures were made to me
in behalf of one of the great major-league

3260.text:
teams; but in the tightest pitch that ever
had confronted me in the past I had never

3265.text: been in such need for control as now.

3268.text:
As I wound up for the delivery, I held my
nerves and muscles under absolute command,

3273.text:
though the grinning jaws were hurtling toward
me at terrific speed. And then I let go, with

3280.text:
every ounce of my weight and muscle and science
in back of that throw. The stone caught the

3286.text:
hyaenodon full upon the end of the nose, and
sent him bowling over upon his back.

3291.text:
At the same instant a chorus of shrieks and
howls arose from the circle of spectators,

3296.text:
so that for a moment I thought that the upsetting
of their champion was the cause; but in this

3302.text:
I soon saw that I was mistaken. As I looked,
the ape-things broke in all directions toward

3307.text:
the surrounding hills, and then I distinguished
the real cause of their perturbation. Behind

3313.text:
them, streaming through the pass which leads
into the valley, came a swarm of hairy men—gorilla-like

3319.text:
creatures armed with spears and hatchets,
and bearing long, oval shields. Like demons

3325.text:
they set upon the ape-things, and before them
the hyaenodon, which had now regained its

3331.text:
senses and its feet, fled howling with fright.
Past us swept the pursued and the pursuers,

3338.text:
nor did the hairy ones accord us more than
a passing glance until the arena had been

3342.text:
emptied of its former occupants. Then they
returned to us, and one who seemed to have

3348.text:
authority among them directed that we be brought
with them.

3352.text:
When we had passed out of the amphitheater
onto the great plain we saw a caravan of men

3357.text:
and women—human beings like ourselves—and
for the first time hope and relief filled

3362.text:
my heart, until I could have cried out in
the exuberance of my happiness. It is true

3368.text:
that they were a half-naked, wild-appearing
aggregation; but they at least were fashioned

3373.text:
along the same lines as ourselves—there
was nothing grotesque or horrible about them

3378.text:
as about the other creatures in this strange,
weird world.

3383.text:
But as we came closer, our hearts sank once
more, for we discovered that the poor wretches

3389.text:
were chained neck to neck in a long line,
and that the gorilla-men were their guards.

3395.text:
With little ceremony Perry and I were chained
at the end of the line, and without further

3400.text: ado the interrupted march was resumed.

3403.text:
Up to this time the excitement had kept us
both up; but now the tiresome monotony of

3409.text:
the long march across the sun-baked plain
brought on all the agonies consequent to a

3415.text:
long-denied sleep. On and on we stumbled beneath
that hateful noonday sun. If we fell we were

3422.text:
prodded with a sharp point. Our companions
in chains did not stumble. They strode along

3428.text:
proudly erect. Occasionally they would exchange
words with one another in a monosyllabic language.

3434.text:
They were a noble-appearing race with well-formed
heads and perfect physiques. The men were

3441.text:
heavily bearded, tall and muscular; the women,
smaller and more gracefully molded, with great

3447.text:
masses of raven hair caught into loose knots
upon their heads. The features of both sexes

3454.text:
were well proportioned—there was not a face
among them that would have been called even

3458.text:
plain if judged by earthly standards. They
wore no ornaments; but this I later learned

3465.text:
was due to the fact that their captors had
stripped them of everything of value. As garmenture

3470.text:
the women possessed a single robe of some
light-colored, spotted hide, rather similar

3476.text:
in appearance to a leopard's skin. This they
wore either supported entirely about the waist

3481.text:
by a leathern thong, so that it hung partially
below the knee on one side, or possibly looped

3487.text:
gracefully across one shoulder. Their feet
were shod with skin sandals. The men wore

3493.text:
loin cloths of the hide of some shaggy beast,
long ends of which depended before and behind

3499.text:
nearly to the ground. In some instances these
ends were finished with the strong talons

3505.text:
of the beast from which the hides had been
taken.

3508.text:
Our guards, whom I already have described
as gorilla-like men, were rather lighter in

3514.text:
build than a gorilla, but even so they were
indeed mighty creatures. Their arms and legs

3519.text:
were proportioned more in conformity with
human standards, but their entire bodies were

3524.text:
covered with shaggy, brown hair, and their
faces were quite as brutal as those of the

3530.text:
few stuffed specimens of the gorilla which
I had seen in the museums at home.

3535.text:
Their only redeeming feature lay in the development
of the head above and back of the ears. In

3541.text:
this respect they were not one whit less human
than we. They were clothed in a sort of tunic

3547.text:
of light cloth which reached to the knees.
Beneath this they wore only a loin cloth of

3552.text:
the same material, while their feet were shod
with thick hide of some mammoth creature of

3560.text:
Their arms and necks were encircled by many
ornaments of metal—silver predominating—and

3565.text:
on their tunics were sewn the heads of tiny
reptiles in odd and rather artistic designs.

3571.text:
They talked among themselves as they marched
along on either side of us, but in a language

3576.text:
which I perceived differed from that employed
by our fellow prisoners. When they addressed

3582.text:
the latter they used what appeared to be a
third language, and which I later learned

3587.text:
is a mongrel tongue rather analogous to the
Pidgin-English of the Chinese coolie.

3593.text:
How far we marched I have no conception, nor
has Perry. Both of us were asleep much of

3599.text:
the time for hours before a halt was called—then
we dropped in our tracks. I say "for hours,"

3606.text:
but how may one measure time where time does
not exist! When our march commenced the sun

3612.text:
stood at zenith. When we halted our shadows
still pointed toward nadir. Whether an instant

3618.text:
or an eternity of earthly time elapsed who
may say. That march may have occupied nine

3625.text:
years and eleven months of the ten years that
I spent in the inner world, or it may have

3630.text:
been accomplished in the fraction of a second—I
cannot tell. But this I do know that since

3636.text:
you have told me that ten years have elapsed
since I departed from this earth I have lost

3641.text:
all respect for time—I am commencing to
doubt that such a thing exists other than

3647.text: in the weak, finite mind of man.

3656.text:
WHEN OUR GUARDS AROUSED US FROM SLEEP WE were
much refreshed. They gave us food. Strips

3663.text:
of dried meat it was, but it put new life
and strength into us, so that now we too marched

3669.text:
with high-held heads, and took noble strides.
At least I did, for I was young and proud;

3676.text:
but poor Perry hated walking. On earth I had
often seen him call a cab to travel a square—he

3682.text:
was paying for it now, and his old legs wobbled
so that I put my arm about him and half carried

3687.text:
him through the balance of those frightful
marches.

3691.text:
The country began to change at last, and we
wound up out of the level plain through mighty

3695.text:
mountains of virgin granite. The tropical
verdure of the lowlands was replaced by hardier

3701.text:
vegetation, but even here the effects of constant
heat and light were apparent in the immensity

3706.text:
of the trees and the profusion of foliage
and blooms. Crystal streams roared through

3711.text:
their rocky channels, fed by the perpetual
snows which we could see far above us. Above

3717.text:
the snowcapped heights hung masses of heavy
clouds. It was these, Perry explained, which

3723.text:
evidently served the double purpose of replenishing
the melting snows and protecting them from

3727.text: the direct rays of the sun.

3730.text:
By this time we had picked up a smattering
of the bastard language in which our guards

3734.text:
addressed us, as well as making good headway
in the rather charming tongue of our co-captives.

3741.text:
Directly ahead of me in the chain gang was
a young woman. Three feet of chain linked

3745.text:
us together in a forced companionship which
I, at least, soon rejoiced in. For I found

3752.text:
her a willing teacher, and from her I learned
the language of her tribe, and much of the

3757.text:
life and customs of the inner world—at least
that part of it with which she was familiar.

3763.text:
She told me that she was called Dian the Beautiful,
and that she belonged to the tribe of Amoz,

3768.text:
which dwells in the cliffs above the Darel
Az, or shallow sea.

3773.text: "How came you here?" I asked her.

3776.text:
"I was running away from Jubal the Ugly One,"
she answered, as though that was explanation

3783.text:
"Who is Jubal the Ugly One?" I asked. "And
why did you run away from him?"

3789.text: She looked at me in surprise.

3791.text:
"Why DOES a woman run away from a man?" she
answered my question with another.

3797.text:
"They do not, where I come from," I replied.
"Sometimes they run after them."

3803.text:
But she could not understand. Nor could I
get her to grasp the fact that I was of another

3809.text:
world. She was quite as positive that creation
was originated solely to produce her own kind

3815.text:
and the world she lived in as are many of
the outer world.

3818.text:
"But Jubal," I insisted. "Tell me about him,
and why you ran away to be chained by the

3824.text: neck and scourged across the face of a world."

3828.text:
"Jubal the Ugly One placed his trophy before
my father's house. It was the head of a mighty

3834.text:
tandor. It remained there and no greater trophy
was placed beside it. So I knew that Jubal

3840.text:
the Ugly One would come and take me as his
mate. None other so powerful wished me, or

3846.text:
they would have slain a mightier beast and
thus have won me from Jubal. My father is

3851.text:
not a mighty hunter. Once he was, but a sadok
tossed him, and never again had he the full

3858.text:
use of his right arm. My brother, Dacor the
Strong One, had gone to the land of Sari to

3863.text:
steal a mate for himself. Thus there was none,
father, brother, or lover, to save me from

3869.text:
Jubal the Ugly One, and I ran away and hid
among the hills that skirt the land of Amoz.

3875.text:
And there these Sagoths found me and made
me captive."

3878.text:
"What will they do with you?" I asked. "Where
are they taking us?"

3886.text:
"I can almost believe that you are of another
world," she said, "for otherwise such ignorance

3893.text:
were inexplicable. Do you really mean that
you do not know that the Sagoths are the creatures

3898.text:
of the Mahars—the mighty Mahars who think
they own Pellucidar and all that walks or

3903.text:
grows upon its surface, or creeps or burrows
beneath, or swims within its lakes and oceans,

3908.text:
or flies through its air? Next you will be
telling me that you never before heard of

3915.text:
I was loath to do it, and further incur her
scorn; but there was no alternative if I were

3921.text:
to absorb knowledge, so I made a clean breast
of my pitiful ignorance as to the mighty Mahars.

3928.text:
She was shocked. But she did her very best
to enlighten me, though much that she said

3933.text:
was as Greek would have been to her. She described
the Mahars largely by comparisons. In this

3939.text:
way they were like unto thipdars, in that
to the hairless lidi.

3943.text:
About all I gleaned of them was that they
were quite hideous, had wings, and webbed

3949.text:
feet; lived in cities built beneath the ground;
could swim under water for great distances,

3954.text:
and were very, very wise. The Sagoths were
their weapons of offense and defense, and

3961.text:
the races like herself were their hands and
feet—they were the slaves and servants who

3965.text:
did all the manual labor. The Mahars were
the heads—the brains—of the inner world.

3971.text: I longed to see this wondrous race of supermen.

3976.text:
Perry learned the language with me. When we
halted, as we occasionally did, though sometimes

3981.text:
the halts seemed ages apart, he would join
in the conversation, as would Ghak the Hairy

3986.text:
One, he who was chained just ahead of Dian
the Beautiful. Ahead of Ghak was Hooja the

3992.text:
Sly One. He too entered the conversation occasionally.
Most of his remarks were directed toward Dian

3999.text:
the Beautiful. It didn't take half an eye
to see that he had developed a bad case; but

4004.text:
the girl appeared totally oblivious to his
thinly veiled advances. Did I say thinly veiled?

4010.text:
There is a race of men in New Zealand, or
Australia, I have forgotten which, who indicate

4015.text:
their preference for the lady of their affections
by banging her over the head with a bludgeon.

4020.text:
By comparison with this method Hooja's lovemaking
might be called thinly veiled. At first it

4027.text:
caused me to blush violently although I have
seen several Old Years out at Rectors, and

4032.text:
in other less fashionable places off Broadway,
and in Vienna, and Hamburg.

4037.text:
But the girl! She was magnificent. It was
easy to see that she considered herself as

4044.text:
entirely above and apart from her present
surroundings and company. She talked with

4049.text:
me, and with Perry, and with the taciturn
Ghak because we were respectful; but she couldn't

4055.text:
even see Hooja the Sly One, much less hear
him, and that made him furious. He tried to

4062.text:
get one of the Sagoths to move the girl up
ahead of him in the slave gang, but the fellow

4067.text:
only poked him with his spear and told him
that he had selected the girl for his own

4071.text:
property—that he would buy her from the
Mahars as soon as they reached Phutra. Phutra,

4077.text: it seemed, was the city of our destination.

4081.text:
After passing over the first chain of mountains
we skirted a salt sea, upon whose bosom swam

4086.text:
countless horrid things. Seal-like creatures
there were with long necks stretching ten

4093.text:
and more feet above their enormous bodies
and whose snake heads were split with gaping

4098.text:
mouths bristling with countless fangs. There
were huge tortoises too, paddling about among

4104.text:
these other reptiles, which Perry said were
Plesiosaurs of the Lias. I didn't question

4110.text: his veracity—they might have been most anything.

4114.text:
Dian told me they were tandorazes, or tandors
of the sea, and that the other, and more fearsome

4120.text:
reptiles, which occasionally rose from the
deep to do battle with them, were azdyryths,

4125.text:
or sea-dyryths—Perry called them Ichthyosaurs.
They resembled a whale with the head of an

4132.text:
I had forgotten what little geology I had
studied at school—about all that remained

4137.text:
was an impression of horror that the illustrations
of restored prehistoric monsters had made

4142.text:
upon me, and a well-defined belief that any
man with a pig's shank and a vivid imagination

4148.text:
could "restore" most any sort of paleolithic
monster he saw fit, and take rank as a first

4153.text:
class paleontologist. But when I saw these
sleek, shiny carcasses shimmering in the sunlight

4160.text:
as they emerged from the ocean, shaking their
giant heads; when I saw the waters roll from

4165.text:
their sinuous bodies in miniature waterfalls
as they glided hither and thither, now upon

4170.text:
the surface, now half submerged; as I saw
them meet, open-mouthed, hissing and snorting,

4177.text:
in their titanic and interminable warring
I realized how futile is man's poor, weak

4182.text:
imagination by comparison with Nature's incredible
genius.

4187.text:
And Perry! He was absolutely flabbergasted.
He said so himself.

4193.text:
"David," he remarked, after we had marched
for a long time beside that awful sea. "David,

4199.text:
I used to teach geology, and I thought that
I believed what I taught; but now I see that

4205.text:
I did not believe it—that it is impossible
for man to believe such things as these unless

4210.text:
he sees them with his own eyes. We take things
for granted, perhaps, because we are told

4216.text:
them over and over again, and have no way
of disproving them—like religions, for example;

4221.text:
but we don't believe them, we only think we
do. If you ever get back to the outer world

4227.text:
you will find that the geologists and paleontologists
will be the first to set you down a liar,

4233.text:
for they know that no such creatures as they
restore ever existed. It is all right to IMAGINE

4239.text:
them as existing in an equally imaginary epoch—but
now? poof!"

4245.text:
At the next halt Hooja the Sly One managed
to find enough slack chain to permit him to

4250.text:
worm himself back quite close to Dian. We
were all standing, and as he edged near the

4256.text:
girl she turned her back upon him in such
a truly earthly feminine manner that I could

4261.text:
scarce repress a smile; but it was a short-lived
smile for on the instant the Sly One's hand

4268.text:
fell upon the girl's bare arm, jerking her
roughly toward him.

4273.text:
I was not then familiar with the customs or
social ethics which prevailed within Pellucidar;

4279.text:
but even so I did not need the appealing look
which the girl shot to me from her magnificent

4283.text:
eyes to influence my subsequent act. What
the Sly One's intention was I paused not to

4290.text:
inquire; but instead, before he could lay
hold of her with his other hand, I placed

4294.text:
a right to the point of his jaw that felled
him in his tracks.

4298.text:
A roar of approval went up from those of the
other prisoners and the Sagoths who had witnessed

4303.text:
the brief drama; not, as I later learned,
because I had championed the girl, but for

4308.text:
the neat and, to them, astounding method by
which I had bested Hooja.

4313.text:
And the girl? At first she looked at me with
wide, wondering eyes, and then she dropped

4318.text:
her head, her face half averted, and a delicate
flush suffused her cheek. For a moment she

4325.text:
stood thus in silence, and then her head went
high, and she turned her back upon me as she

4330.text:
had upon Hooja. Some of the prisoners laughed,
and I saw the face of Ghak the Hairy One go

4336.text:
very black as he looked at me searchingly.
And what I could see of Dian's cheek went

4345.text:
Immediately after we resumed the march, and
though I realized that in some way I had offended

4350.text:
Dian the Beautiful I could not prevail upon
her to talk with me that I might learn wherein

4355.text:
I had erred—in fact I might quite as well
have been addressing a sphinx for all the

4360.text:
attention I got. At last my own foolish pride
stepped in and prevented my making any further

4367.text:
attempts, and thus a companionship that without
my realizing it had come to mean a great deal

4372.text:
to me was cut off. Thereafter I confined my
conversation to Perry. Hooja did not renew

4379.text:
his advances toward the girl, nor did he again
venture near me.

4385.text:
Again the weary and apparently interminable
marching became a perfect nightmare of horrors

4390.text:
to me. The more firmly fixed became the realization
that the girl's friendship had meant so much

4395.text:
to me, the more I came to miss it; and the
more impregnable the barrier of silly pride.

4402.text:
But I was very young and would not ask Ghak
for the explanation which I was sure he could

4407.text:
give, and that might have made everything
all right again.

4411.text:
On the march, or during halts, Dian refused
consistently to notice me—when her eyes

4417.text:
wandered in my direction she looked either
over my head or directly through me. At last

4423.text:
I became desperate, and determined to swallow
my self-esteem, and again beg her to tell

4428.text:
me how I had offended, and how I might make
reparation. I made up my mind that I should

4433.text:
do this at the next halt. We were approaching
another range of mountains at the time, and

4439.text:
when we reached them, instead of winding across
them through some high-flung pass we entered

4444.text:
a mighty natural tunnel—a series of labyrinthine
grottoes, dark as Erebus.

4451.text:
The guards had no torches or light of any
description. In fact we had seen no artificial

4456.text:
light or sign of fire since we had entered
Pellucidar. In a land of perpetual noon there

4462.text:
is no need of light above ground, yet I marveled
that they had no means of lighting their way

4467.text:
through these dark, subterranean passages.
So we crept along at a snail's pace, with

4473.text:
much stumbling and falling—the guards keeping
up a singsong chant ahead of us, interspersed

4479.text:
with certain high notes which I found always
indicated rough places and turns.

4485.text:
Halts were now more frequent, but I did not
wish to speak to Dian until I could see from

4490.text:
the expression of her face how she was receiving
my apologies. At last a faint glow ahead forewarned

4496.text:
us of the end of the tunnel, for which I for
one was devoutly thankful. Then at a sudden

4503.text:
turn we emerged into the full light of the
noonday sun.

4507.text:
But with it came a sudden realization of what
meant to me a real catastrophe—Dian was

4513.text:
gone, and with her a half-dozen other prisoners.
The guards saw it too, and the ferocity of

4519.text:
their rage was terrible to behold. Their awesome,
bestial faces were contorted in the most diabolical

4526.text:
expressions, as they accused each other of
responsibility for the loss. Finally they

4531.text:
fell upon us, beating us with their spear
shafts, and hatchets. They had already killed

4536.text:
two near the head of the line, and were like
to have finished the balance of us when their

4540.text:
leader finally put a stop to the brutal slaughter.
Never in all my life had I witnessed a more

4547.text:
horrible exhibition of bestial rage—I thanked
God that Dian had not been one of those left

4555.text:
Of the twelve prisoners who had been chained
ahead of me each alternate one had been freed

4559.text:
commencing with Dian. Hooja was gone. Ghak
remained. What could it mean? How had it been

4566.text:
accomplished? The commander of the guards
was investigating. Soon he discovered that

4571.text:
the rude locks which had held the neckbands
in place had been deftly picked.

4575.text:
"Hooja the Sly One," murmured Ghak, who was
now next to me in line. "He has taken the

4582.text:
girl that you would not have," he continued,
glancing at me.

4586.text:
"That I would not have!" I cried. "What do
you mean?"

4591.text: He looked at me closely for a moment.

4593.text:
"I have doubted your story that you are from
another world," he said at last, "but yet

4600.text:
upon no other grounds could your ignorance
of the ways of Pellucidar be explained. Do

4605.text:
you really mean that you do not know that
you offended the Beautiful One, and how?"

4609.text: "I do not know, Ghak," I replied.

4613.text:
"Then shall I tell you. When a man of Pellucidar
intervenes between another man and the woman

4619.text:
the other man would have, the woman belongs
to the victor. Dian the Beautiful belongs

4624.text:
to you. You should have claimed her or released
her. Had you taken her hand, it would have

4630.text:
